Kevin_Denney:
{{short description|American singer-songwriter}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2020}} {{BLP sources|date=January 2008}} {{Infobox musical artist |image= | | name = Kevin Denney | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1978|01|27}} | origin = | instrument = Vocals, acoustic guitar | genre = [[country music|Country]] | occupation = Singer-songwriter | years_active = 2001–present | label = [[Lyric Street Records|Lyric Street]] | associated_acts = [[Tracy Byrd]]
[[Easton Corbin]]
[[Craig Morgan (singer)|Craig Morgan]] }} '''Kevin Denney''' (born January 27, 1978){{Cite web |last=Rose |first=Mike |date=January 27, 2020|title=Today's famous birthdays list for January 27, 2020 includes celebrities Alan Cumming, James Cromwell|url=https://www.cleveland.com/life-and-culture/j66j-2020/01/abe688f7241977/todays-famous-birthdays-list-for-january-27-2020-includes-celebrities-james-cromwell-mimi-rogers.html |access-date=January 27, 2023 |website=[[Cleveland.com]]}} is an American [[country music]] artist. Signed to [[Lyric Street Records]] in 2001, he made his debut on the country music scene with the release of his self-titled album (2002's ''[[Kevin Denney (album)|Kevin Denney]]''), which produced three chart singles, including "[[That's Just Jessie]]", a Top 20 hit on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Hot Country Singles & Tracks (now [[Hot Country Songs]]) charts. He was dropped from Lyric Street's roster in 2003, although he co-wrote a track on [[Tracy Byrd]]'s 2006 ''[[Different Things]]'' album. ==Biography== Denney's interest in music began at an early age. His mother and father, both of whom sang in a [[gospel music]] quartet, bought Denney his first guitar when he was three years old.{{Cite web|url=https://www.liveabout.com/country-4688258|title=Country|website=LiveAbout.com|accessdate=March 25, 2020}} He also became a frequent listener of the [[Grand Ole Opry]] radio shows, and played in his cousin's [[bluegrass music]] band. At age 17, however, he briefly stopped focusing on his musical interests to re-assess his future. On his eighteenth birthday, his girlfriend took him to a [[George Strait]] concert. Seeing Strait in concert helped Denney discover that music was his passion, and he later joined a local band that was looking for a lead singer. Denney later went solo, and was signed to [[Lyric Street Records]] in 2001.{{cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/kevin-denney-mn0000767883 |title=Kevin Denny |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=January 6, 2022}} His eponymous debut album, released in 2002, produced three charting singles on the [[Hot Country Songs]] charts: "[[That's Just Jessie]]" at number 16, "Cadillac Tears" at number 30 and "It'll Go Away" at number 43.{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2008|page=122|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}} He also contributed a rendition of "[[White Christmas (song)|White Christmas]]" to the label's multi-artist compilation ''No Wrapping Required''.{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r552889|pure_url=yes}}|title=''No Wrapping Required'' review|last=Birchmeier|first=Jason|website=[[AllMusic]]|accessdate=September 22, 2010}} In late 2003, Denney charted a fourth single, "A Year at a Time," which peaked at number 44 on the country charts. The song did not appear on an album, and Denney exited the label. He co-wrote a track on [[Tracy Byrd]]'s 2006 album ''[[Different Things]]'', and [[Craig Morgan (singer)|Craig Morgan]]'s 2009 single "[[Bonfire (Craig Morgan song)|Bonfire]]." He also co-wrote "Don't Ask Me About a Woman", a song recorded by [[Easton Corbin]] on his 2010 [[Easton Corbin (album)|self-titled debut album]]. ==Discography== ===Studio albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:12em;"| Title ! rowspan="2" style="width:16em;"| Album details ! colspan="3"| Peak chart positions |- style="font-size:smaller;" ! width="45"| [[Top Country Albums|US Country]] ! width="45"| [[Billboard 200|US]] ! width="45"| [[Top Heatseekers|US Heat]] |- ! scope="row"| ''[[Kevin Denney (album)|Kevin Denney]]'' | * Release date: April 23, 2002 * Label: [[Lyric Street Records]] | 14 | 119 | 2 |- ! scope="row"| ''Something in Between'' | * Release date: June 24, 2016 * Label: KDM Records | — | — | — |- | colspan="5" style="font-size:8pt"| "—" denotes releases that did not chart |- |} ===Singles=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2"| Year ! rowspan="2" style="width:16em;"| Single ! colspan="2"| Peak chart
